About the DIAS Archive

The DIAS Archive is an ongoing open-source investigation into the role of biometric voice technologies in European asylum systems. It examines how the Dialect Identification Assistance System (DIAS) influences borders, credibility evaluations, and the daily realities of people seeking protection.

What we document

We collect, analyse, and reconstruct how DIAS and related systems operate in practice. Our archive includes technical documentation, legal cases, testimonies, internal material, and research tracing how voice becomes evidence within asylum decision-making.

Why DIAS matters

DIAS plays a subtle but critical role in defining credibility. Its assessments can influence the possibilities of refuge, determining who is believed and who is not. Understanding this system is essential for exposing its political, technological, and ethical implications.

Our approach

This archive operates at the intersection of investigative research, critical algorithm studies, and digital forensics. It is guided by an abolitionist perspective: one that questions the logics of surveillance, categorization, and algorithmic border control.

Quick Facts

  • Introduced: 2017
  • Used by: BAMF (DE), and partners across the EU
  • Technology: Voice classification & dialect profiling
  • Area: Asylum procedures / border infrastructures
